[To M
r
]
Bodly
S
r
. Yowe shall soe largelie understand hir
Ma
ties
intention
by hir letters sent at this time, as I shall not neade to write at
much length unto yowe: but
yet
this I must add unto it, that hir Ma
tie
expecteth at yo
r
handes that yowe will so deale w
th
the
states
and
the
Counsell
that in noe wise this hir Ma
ties
purpose for the drawing
of thes Cumpanies from thence, maie be for anie allegac
o
n delaied,
aswell for the necessitie of the
s
rvice for the publique weale
w
ch
at this time will be greatlie endangered, if the
French
Kinge
be not releved: as for the promise that the
F.
Quene hath
at this time made w
th
the Frenche Kinges
Ambassado
r
Mons
r
de Sonoy
, purposelie sent for yt: so as in vearie trewthe hir Ma
ty
maie not receive deniall by the states, or delaie by hir owne
Capteines and subject
,/ I praie yowe also to enquire of newe
and to rectefie mee the trewthe what the States will yeld unto for
[ordre] of the Frenche K. w
th
men both by land and by sea, as
certaine monethes past theare was an offer made by them: but
speaking w
th
Mons
r
de Caron
theareof I can finde noe certainetie
and therefore I require yowe w
th
speed to deale hearein, and to
reduce the States to su
m
benefitiall offer for the King.
And so for this time wanting leisure to write at more length unto
yowe, I vearye hartelie Commend mee to yowe./ From the
Co
r
t at Grenewich this second of Julie. 1592./
Your very loving frend William Burghley
